text: Well, what we really are is long-term fundamental investors, meaning that at any point in time, all I want to know is all of the publicly available information about a company that can be found in its historical financials or other documents that are filed with the SEC or published online. And all I want to assess is whether this company is going to be a good long-term investment or not. Now, the reality is that when you train any kind of model with that setup, it'll inevitably come up with a model that is characteristically value in nature. And that is just because of the strength of the value effect in the data. It's embedded in the combination of base economic principles of mean reversion and human behavioral biases, which create the effect. And therefore, it's existed for a very, very long time and will continue to exist. Now, with a value model, there is, of course, value investments, good value investments, and there are also value traps. And I think that is where machine learning really shows its power and its ability to use non-linearity to discriminate within the universe of value between companies that are true value opportunities and those companies that are just deservedly cheap.
